10.text: So poultry are a naturally active and inquisitive animal

13.text: so a healthy, a healthy chook should be very active,

16.text: and should be very aware of its surrounds,

18.text: you and the other chooks and it

22.text: So if we start with the head of a healthy chook,

24.text: in the majority of breeds, the healthy chook has

27.text: a bright red comb, face and wattles.

30.text: Fowl pox lesions would cause abnormalities on the head,

34.text: face and wattles of the chook and these present as raised,

39.text: brown to black lesions and indicate infection with the fowl pox

43.text: which can be spread by mosquitoes.

46.text: Moving down the chook, feathers of fowls or chooks

50.text: should be tight, and shiny and free from

56.text: So the healthy chook is a complete chook.

59.text: It’s feathered all over and presents shiny.

63.text: Absence of feathers or broken feathers anywhere on the body

66.text: can indicate the presence of feather pecking in

69.text: that flock of chooks and problems that cause feather pecking

78.text: The legs of poultry are naturally scaled and the bone is round,

83.text: so the healthy chook should have a

85.text: closely scaled, round leg that is shiny.

88.text: The most common problem we see with the scales of poultry

91.text: is when they get infected with the scaly leg mite

93.text: and what that does is cause a roughness to the scale,

96.text: so it loses that smooth round appearance

102.text: So a healthy bird, when you are handling it should have

105.text: round muscles on the breast, and the keel bone,

109.text: which is the sternum of the chook, should not be sharp

112.text: to the hand when holding the bird.

115.text: That indicates good muscling of the fowl and indicates

118.text: adequate nutrition, general health and freedom from disease.

122.text: The beak on a healthy chook, the top beak should

126.text: sit smoothly over the bottom beak.

129.text: If the top beak overgrows the bottom beak too far,

133.text: sometimes it needs to be trimmed.

136.text: When we talk about external parasites of poultry,

139.text: the most common would be lice and mites.

142.text: The lice and the mites are spread by the access

145.text: of the poultry to wild birds so that’s

147.text: an important consideration in shed design.

150.text: So lice is commonly seen as a small, brown and

154.text: rapidly moving creature, most commonly seen on the vent

158.text: of the fowl and you’ll also see clumps of white eggs

162.text: that the lice leave on the poultry.

165.text: So the lice live on, on the fowls 100% of the time

169.text: and they feed on blood and skin from the fowl.

173.text: The poultry will lose condition from irritation

176.text: from infestation with lice, so when we’re considering

180.text: the control of lice firstly if we can restrict the access

184.text: of the birds or the poultry to wild birds that’s going

186.text: to remove a great deal of the lice from the environment.

190.text: However, the application of insecticides, whether that be

193.text: in a spray or in a dust formulation to the poultry

197.text: and to their shedding will reduce the incidence of the lice.

201.text: Red mite are different from lice because they

203.text: do not live on the poultry 100% of the time.

206.text: They actually reside in the shed.

208.text: They like to live in cracks in wood and we particularly

211.text: find that they live in cracks in the wood

216.text: What they do is they leave their environment

219.text: at night time and feed on the poultry.

222.text: This causes intense irritation to the fowls but what

225.text: it does also causes a great deal of blood loss and anaemia

230.text: and we can actually have deaths in poultry

233.text: from blood loss from red mite.

236.text: The most common sign you will see is paleness to the head

239.text: from red mite infestation and if you pick the birds up

242.text: you will actually find scars around the vent of the fowl

245.text: which is where the red mites feed.

248.text: Red mite, again, are transmitted by wild birds

252.text: so we’ve got to consider our shed design or range design

255.text: when we’re considering how birds are becoming infected

260.text: or infested with the red mite and thus how we control it.

263.text: Insecticides are very effective against red mite and

267.text: should be applied to both the birds,

271.text: So we need to ensure that we spray all wooden surfaces,

276.text: litter and nest boxes in the shed to kill the red mite.

281.text: Northern mite differ to red mite because they, like lice,

285.text: spend most of their life on the fowl.

287.text: The northern mite, similar to red mite cause severe anaemia

290.text: in the fowl but also severe irritation.

294.text: They’re controlled similarly to red mite by the application

297.text: of insecticides to the poultry but also

302.text: The easiest way in a school situation to do this

304.text: is to actually get a liquid insecticide, make this up into a

308.text: garden pump pack sprayer and this allows the sheds

312.text: and the birds to be sprayed at once.

315.text: I think it’s more effective and it's simpler.
